question_text:
You have a Fabric workspace that contains a semantic model named Model1.
You need to dynamically execute and monitor the refresh progress of Model1.
What should you use?

answers.A: dynamic management views in Microsoft SQL Server Management Studio (SSMS)
answers.C: dynamic management views in Azure Data Studio
answers.D: a semantic link in a notebook

discussion:
If the definition of "dynamic" is the ability to execute and monitor in real-time, a semantic link in a notebook could be more suitable than the monitoring hub.

B. Monitoring hub

A. dynamic management views in SSMS	DMVs in SSMS are for SQL databases or warehouses â€” not for Fabric semantic models.
B. Monitoring hub	The Monitoring hub shows execution history and status after the refresh starts, but it does not allow dynamic execution or programmatic monitoring.
C. dynamic management views in Azure Data Studio	Same limitation as SSMS â€” works for SQL engines, not semantic models in Fabric.
D. a semantic link in a notebook	âœ… Correct â€” allows dynamic execution (start refresh) and programmatic monitoring of refresh status

B. Monitoring hub

ðŸ§  Explanation:
The Monitoring hub in Microsoft Fabric is designed to track and monitor refresh progress of semantic models (like Model1) in real time.
It provides status updates, duration, success/failure logs, and refresh history.
Why not the others?
A & C (DMVs in SSMS/Azure Data Studio): These are used for querying metadata but donâ€™t support dynamic execution or real-time monitoring in Fabric.
D (Semantic link in a notebook): Used for querying semantic models, not for refreshing or monitoring them.

Maybe the idea behind a dynamic execution it so take action based on the failed refresh so like a retry or something? It makes sense to be semantic link then.

Semantic links are used to query semantic models from notebooks, not for monitoring refresh progress. In Monitoring hub its possible to monitor the refresh status and execute whenever you wish

The correct answer is: B. Monitoring hub
In Microsoft Fabric, the Monitoring hub is the appropriate tool to dynamically execute and monitor the refresh progress of semantic models like Model1. It provides visibility into refresh operations, including status, duration, and any errors encountered.
Hereâ€™s why the other options are not suitable:
â€¢	A. Dynamic management views in SSMS: These are used for SQL Server databases, not for monitoring semantic model refreshes in Fabric.
â€¢	C. Dynamic management views in Azure Data Studio: Similar to SSMS, these are for database-level diagnostics, not for semantic model refresh tracking in Fabric.
â€¢	D. A semantic link in a notebook: Semantic links allow querying semantic models from notebooks but do not provide monitoring capabilities for refresh operations.
Ref: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/fabric/data-factory/semantic-model-refresh-activity

Let me correct that: 
Correct is option D (Semantic link in a notebook) because allows both actions:
-Dynamically triggering the refresh (using Python, Spark, or KQL code)
-Monitoring the status and progress from the same notebook, even reacting to errors

So, Why Is the Official Answer Still B. Monitoring hub?
Scenario	Best Option
Manual / UI-based monitoring	âœ… Monitoring hub
Automated / programmatic monitoring	âœ… Notebook + semantic link (your method)

So your code is valid and powerful, especially for automation or scheduled monitoring, but if the exam or question context is asking for standard UI tools, then Monitoring hub (B) is the expected answer.
